hackathon-requirements:
The submission should be your best attempt at a functioning application or integration; do not be too worried if the submission doesn't work. 5-6 hours is a very short amount of time to build a project from start to finish, and the judges understand this. Don't be afraid to be ambitious with your project, as long as you can submit a prototype within the 6-hour timeframe.
Your writeup should include a brief description of the submission.
hackathon-rules:
Submissions must be made by 5:15pm on 3/31 - do not abuse the 15 minute grace period!
Teams of up to 4 participants can be formed.
By submitting a project to this hackathon, you are allowing ACM, Google Developers Group, SafeTrek, and any other organizations sponsoring this hackathon to display the project on their website; for more information on ownership rights of the code, please speak to representatives of the sponsoring organizations at the event. 
Prizes will be awarded based on the judging criteria established by the sponsors and specified elsewhere in the DevPost page; ACM and the sponsors reserve the right to award these prizes as they deem fit.

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: This will be awarded to the best Android app submission.

The three best SafeTrek API integrations will each win $100 Amazon gift cards! Integrations will be judged based on the successful integration of API, the creativity displayed in the use case, and overall execution.
Will be emailed after the event.

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: Was your app idea innovative? 6 hours is not a lot of time to write code, and the judges completely understand that; be ambitious! As long as you have a reasonably-working prototype, you're fine - we're not expecting a fully-polished product in 6 hours.
Successful integration of API, creativity displayed in use case, and overall execution.

hackathon-location-description: Hillman 60, Washington University in St. Louis
